post_text:
As we prepare for the 2020-2021 school year, we would like to provide you and your student with these handy tips on how to prepare for in person learning.

Tip number 9: Staying Healthy
If a member of your family is sick with a cold, the flu or Covid-19 follow public health guidelines. Do not return your child to school until clearance is given or by following doctor‚Äôs orders. Students who come to school sick will be sent home.

To learn more tips, see our website at: https://longviewschools.com/2020/09/02/10-things-you-can-do-to-prepare-for-in-person-learning/

post_text:
As we prepare for the 2020-2021 school year, we would like to provide you and your student with ten handy tips on how to prepare for in person learning.

Tip number 8: Cover Sneezes & Coughs
Explain to your child how to cover their mouth and nose when sneezing or coughing. Teach kids how to immediately wash their hands after a sneeze or cough. Be a good role model to positively reinforce the behavior.

To learn more tips, see our website at: https://longviewschools.com/2020/09/02/10-things-you-can-do-to-prepare-for-in-person-learning/

post_text:
As we prepare for the 2020-2021 school year, we would like to provide you and your student with ten handy tips on how to prepare for in person learning.

Tip number 7: Physical Distancing
Staying 6 feet away from the people around you helps limit the chances of an infection being spread. Explain to your child what physical distancing means and how to do it. Practice physical distancing at home and it will be easier for kids when they reach school.

To learn more tips, see our website at: https://longviewschools.com/2020/09/02/10-things-you-can-do-to-prepare-for-in-person-learning/

post_text:
As we prepare for the 2020-2021 school year, we would like to provide you and your student with ten handy tips on how to prepare for in person learning.

Tip number 6: Update Emergency Contact Information
It is critical for schools to be able to reach parents and families in the event of an emergency. If your information is not up to date, call your school and ask them to update your records in Skyward with your current phone number and email address. If students have the symptoms for Covid-19, they will need to be picked up from school immediately.

To learn more tips, see our website at: https://longviewschools.com/2020/09/02/10-things-you-can-do-to-prepare-for-in-person-learning/

Tip number 5: Update Vaccinations
Getting vaccinated is a requirement for coming to school. (Unless you qualify for an exemption.) Getting vaccinated helps limit the transmission of diseases. Have your child‚Äôs immunizations updated prior to returning to in person school.

To learn more tips, see our website at: https://longviewschools.com/2020/09/02/10-things-you-can-do-to-prepare-for-in-person-learning/

post_text:
As we prepare for the 2020-2021 school year, we would like to provide you and your student with ten handy tips on how to prepare for in person learning.

Tip number 4: Stay Home When Sick
Know when your child needs to stay home. Understand when your child needs to stay home from school due to Covid symptoms such as trouble breathing, persistent pain or pressure. Purchase a thermometer and keep your student home if their temperature is 100.4 or higher.

To learn more tips, see our website at: https://longviewschools.com/2020/09/02/10-things-you-can-do-to-prepare-for-in-person-learning/

Tip number 3: Update Medical Information
Update medical plans and medications. Visit your doctor, as needed, if you have a chronic health issue to make sure prescriptions are updated. Notify your school principal or nurse of medical conditions.

As we prepare for the 2020-2021 school year, we would like to provide you and your student with ten handy tips on how to prepare for in person learning.

Tip number 2: Face Coverings
Teach your child how, when and where to wear a face covering. Discuss safety with your children and practice putting on and taking off a face covering to avoid touching the inside of the mask.

To learn more tips, see our website at: https://longviewschools.com/2020/09/02/10-things-you-can-do-to-prepare-for-in-person-learning/
text:
As we prepare for the 2020-2021 school year, we would like to provide you and your student with ten handy tips on how to prepare for in person learning.

Tip number 2: Face Coverings
Teach your child how, when and where to wear a face covering. Discuss safety with your children and practice putting on and taking off a face covering to avoid touching the inside of the mask.

To learn more tips, see our website at: https://longviewschools.com/2020/09/02/10-things-you-can-do-to-prepare-for-in-person-learning/

post_text: We would like to welcome our students to another exciting school year! Hope you all have a fantastic first day of remote learning! Send us photos of your child learning remotely and we will post them to this Facebook page. infoteam@longviewschools.org

post_text:
As we prepare for the 2020-2021 school year, we would like to provide you and your student with ten handy tips on how to prepare for in person learning.

Tip number 1: Practice Hand Washing
Teach children when and how to wash their hands with soap and water. Role model the behavior and provide positive reinforcement.

To learn more tips, see our website at: https://longviewschools.com/2020/09/02/10-things-you-can-do-to-prepare-for-in-person-learning/

post_text:
On Monday, August 31, the U.S. Department of Agriculture extended the free summer meal program to December 31, 2020. What this means is Longview Schools will continue providing free meals to those who need them at selected schools and the four mobile pick up locations.

Starting Tuesday, September 8, meals will be distributed at the locations and times below. Both a breakfast and lunch will be distributed each day and the meals are free to any child age 0 to 18. The meals will be served Monday through Friday.

For more information, click the link below:
https://longviewschools.com/2020/09/02/district-to-continue-feeding-those-in-need/

post_text:
Does your student need school supplies?
The Cowlitz Foot Patrol will be handing out free backpacks with school supplies to local students in grades K-12 this Sunday, August 23 from 1:00 ‚Äì 5:00 p.m. This will be a ‚Äúdrive thru‚Äù event at Monticello Middle School back parking lot, and is open to all students. Please wear your masks, and practice social distancing as you make your way in and out of the parking lot. Volunteers will hand out the backpacks your children need for elementary, middle and high school. Promptly exit the area once you receive them. The address for Monticello Middle School is 1225 28th Avenue.
text:
Does your student need school supplies?
The Cowlitz Foot Patrol will be handing out free backpacks with school supplies to local students in grades K-12 this Sunday, August 23 from 1:00 ‚Äì 5:00 p.m. This will be a ‚Äúdrive thru‚Äù event at Monticello Middle School back parking lot, and is open to all students. Please wear your masks, and practice social distancing as you make your way in and out of the parking lot. Volunteers will hand out the backpacks your children need for elementary, middle and high school. Promptly exit the area once you receive them. The address for Monticello Middle School is 1225 28th Avenue.

post_text:
Because COVID-19 closed our schools, your children may be eligible for food assistance, called Pandemic EBT (P-EBT): Emergency School Meals Program.

P-EBT provides families with funds to make up for the cost of meals while school was closed. This benefit is for Washington children in grades k-12 who receive free or reduced-price school meals. These benefits will be on an Electronic Benefits Transfer (EBT) card, which is used like a debit card to buy groceries.

If your family has lost income since schools closed, you may be eligible for free or reduced-price school meals. You can find out if you are eligible and how to apply by visiting www.k12.wa.us/PEBT.

post_text: LCC Head Start/EHS/ECEAP is now enrolling 3 and 4 year olds. With eight different locations in Cowlitz County, Head Start/EHS/ECEAP provides free preschool, promotes kindergarten readiness, parent engagement, nutrition, medical, dental, and mental health services. Classes to begin September 2020. Apply now! Online: https://lowercolumbia.edu/head-start/apply.php By phone: 360-442-2800

post_text:
We would like to congratulate Ella Aguirre for receiving the National Junior Honor Society's Outstanding Student Achievement Award! Recipients of this award are chosen based on their demonstrated work to support the five pillars of NJHS: scholarship, service, leadership, character, and citizenship. To win this award, Ella wrote essays, participated in community service events, demonstrated leadership skills, maintained a high GPA all three years of middle school, and showed integrity in all aspects of her life.

Let's give this amazing student a hand!

We would like to congratulate Ella Aguirre for receiving the National Junior Honor Society's Outstanding Student Achievement Award! To win this award, Ella wrote essays, participated in community service events, demonstrated leadership skills, maintained a high GPA all three years of middle school, and showed integrity in all aspects of her life.

Let's give this amazing student a hand!

The Star Polisher project invites students to share stories about school staff members who have helped them become successful at school. Today we are sharing one of their stories.

What is your first name?
Jaslyn ‚Äì Monticello

Tell us who you would like to thank for being a "star polisher".
Mrs.Gould

How did this person make a difference in your life?
She makes math really fun and exciting, therefore I would like to thank her for being awesome.

If you'd like to submit a Star Polisher please send it to infoteam@longviewschools.org.

post_text:
The Star Polisher project invites students to share stories about school staff members who have helped them become successful at school. Today we are sharing one of their stories.

What is your first name?
Destany ‚Äì Mark Morris

Tell us who you would like to thank for being a "star polisher".
Mr. Ulman, Mark Morris HS History Teacher.

How did this person make a difference in your life?
Mr. Ulman is a god among men. You could ask any student of his and they would all agree- Mr. Ulman carried AP U.S. History on his back. There is no other former football coach that I would rather have to teach us history. He made a boring subject worth learning with his humor and methods of teaching. I will never forget all the sad dog videos we watched in that class.

If you'd like to submit a Star Polisher please send it to infoteam@longviewschools.org.

The Star Polisher project invites students to share stories about school staff members who have helped them become successful at school. Today we are sharing one of their stories.

What is your first name?
Henry ‚Äì Northlake

Tell us who you would like to thank for being a "star polisher".
Mrs. Smith

How did this person make a difference in your life?
Mrs. Smith is probably one of my favorite teachers so far. She has made a difference in my life because she has taught me something that will probably make difference in life later on. I don't know what that something is but I will when I am in that moment.

If you'd like to submit a Star Polisher please send it to infoteam@longviewschools.org.

post_text:
Lower Columbia School Gardens will be giving away free plants and seeds tomorrow at Archie Anderson Park from 11:30am - 12:00pm.

This event is for families that haven't had a chance to pick up gardening supplies at previous drop off locations.

For more information, please see the post below.
shared_text:
Steve the Rabbit
May 18 at 8:57 PM ¬∑

It's the beginning of a new week and we hope that you are well üíö

Tomorrow/Tuesday 5/19 we'll be at Archie Anderson Park in the Longview Highlands to share free plants and seeds with families who haven't yet had a chance to take home some of our free gardening supplies. (This will be our only distribution site for the week)

üåø Tuesday 5/19 @ Archie Anderson Park from 11:30-noon üåø

Please continue to use physical distancing (6 ft away from any folks who don't live in your household). We'll have white boards and go-go-gadget extension arms ü§ñ to help with some of the logistical challenges that distancing can present!

Home delivery of items will continue to be offered as needed! You can reach us by call or text at 360-200-8918 with any questions or requests, and we'll do our best to accommodate.

post_text: Take a listen to the latest video from the Mark Morris High School Choir!
shared_text:
YOUTUBE.COM
Mark Morris High School: Unclouded Day, Virtual Choir

Mark Morris High School Choir
May 17 at 6:01 PM ¬∑

Hello all-

Enjoy this virtual choir video of the 2019-20 Chamber Choir singing "Unclouded Day" arr. Shawn Kirchner.

This has been quite the project!!

Our very own choir member Skyler McCoy audio engineered and mixed the audio.

We were about to depart on our choir tour when everything shut down. This ensemble had this song READY!

Although we couldn't perform Kirchner's beautiful arrangement together in person, we hope this brings inspiration and joy to everyone during this crazy moment in time.

Please share this on all social media platforms.

post_text: Take a look at this fantastic video that was produced by the Mark Morris High School Choir!
shared_text:
YOUTUBE.COM
Breathe Again, Virtual Vocal Jazz

Mark Morris High School Choir
May 15 at 11:44 AM ¬∑

ONE of TWO Virtual Choir posts:

IT‚ÄôS FINISHED!!

Nothing can replace the human experience of performing with one another!

This video at least tries to simulate that feeling, and give a final product to all of the hard work the students have put in.

After Hours was about to embark on our jazz festival circuit season before the school closure. We couldn‚Äôt let all of the hard work go to waste.

So they came together, each in their own homes, and recorded this.

We WILL get through this and be able to Breathe Again!

Please share!

#musicconnectsus

This video at least tries to simulate that feeling, and give a final product to all of the hard work the students have put in.

After Hours was about to embark on our jazz festival circuit season before the school closure. We couldn‚Äôt let all of the hard work go to waste.

So they came together, each in their own homes, and recorded this.

We WILL get through this and be able to Breathe Again!

Please share!

#musicconnectsus

post_text:
The Star Polisher project invites students to share stories about school staff members who have helped them become successful at school. Today we are sharing one of their stories.

What is your first name?
Savannah ‚Äì RAL

Tell us who you would like to thank for being a "star polisher".
Mr. Ruiz

How did this person make a difference in your life?
Mr. Ruiz has helped me discover what I want to do after high school and taught me many things that I will be able to use in my future career in nursing. I have always been interested in the medical field, but Mr. Ruiz has expanded my understanding of the medical field and made me want to be apart of it.

If you'd like to submit a Star Polisher please send it to infoteam@longviewschools.org.

post_text:
We would like to take a moment to celebrate one of our high school seniors!

This is Torie Sampson from Mark Morris. Some of her favorite things about school these past few years were all the band trips she got to take including ones like Marching down Main Street in the parade her Freshman year, going to Canada 2 years and going to Husky Band days for 3 years. She also met some amazing friends that were part of the foreign exchange student program that will be in her life forever. She is hoping to get to go to their country and meet their families some day in the future.

If you would like to celebrate your high school senior, then please send an email with their name, school, photo and what they enjoyed most about high school to infoteam@longviewschools.org.

The Star Polisher project invites students to share stories about school staff members who have helped them become successful at school. Today we are sharing one of their stories.

What is your first name?
Luke ‚Äì Mint Valley

Tell us who you would like to thank for being a "star polisher".
Mrs. Mickelson

How did this person make a difference in your life?
She made a difference in my life for making me like reading about 10X more. In that year I read the whole Percy Jackson series in 1 school year and started loving Rick Riordan's books. I also read Harry Potter, because in her class we read the first one. Because of that I wanted to finish them, so I did last year. Thank Mrs. Mickelson!

If you'd like to submit a Star Polisher please send it to infoteam@longviewschools.org.

post_text:
The Star Polisher project invites students to share stories about school staff members who have helped them become successful at school. Today we are sharing one of their stories.

What is your first name?
Delfina - Monticello

Tell us who you would like to thank for being a "star polisher".
I would like to thank Ms.Velke

How did this person make a difference in your life?
I would like to thank Ms.Velke because I come into school every morning to her smiling at me and other students. She also asks how I am. She believes in me, and if I push myself I can do great things in life.

If you'd like to submit a Star Polisher please send it to infoteam@longviewschools.org.

post_text: Hi Everyone, a question came in about the flashing yellow school zone lights still on at some school locations. The lights are still on at the schools where meal distribution takes place because children are present. The city controls the lights and has turned them off at schools not serving meals. Thank you.

post_text: Get your garden ready with your student by joining the Master Gardeners free Online Workshop on April 14th from 12:00pm-12:30pm. More information is located at the bottom of this post.
shared_text:
Kelso Longview Chamber of Commerce
April 10 at 2:01 PM ¬∑

On April 14 at 12:00 ‚Äì 12:30 pm, WSU Master Gardeners will present FREE on-line class on Planning Your Garden-Steps to Success. Register and contact Gary Fredricks at garyf@wsu.edu or 360-577-3014 Ext. 3 for connection information. A 20 minute presentation followed by questions will help you learn how to plan your garden for a successful growing season. The program can be accessed on-line by Zoom or by calling in by phone.
The workshop is sponsored by Washington State University Extension Master Gardeners

shared_text:
ESD 112
April 7 at 1:47 AM ¬∑

With WA schools transitioning to online learning for the remainder of the school year, it will be important for families to develop and stick to a healthy schedule. A routine can help you feel more grounded in an otherwise chaotic time. Make a daily plan that includes dedicated times for things like study, play, meals, chores and rest for everyone. Find more healthy tips at https://bit.ly/39y5ObQ.

The sooner we hunker down, the sooner we can get through this together.
Stop the spread of COVID-19 by staying home and staying healthy.
Go out for essential services and exercise only, and practice social distancing (6 feet). Grocery stores, doctor‚Äôs offices and other essential businesses will remain open. The more of us who stay home, the fewer of us will be infected by COVID-19, and more lives will be saved.

post_text:
On a mission to improve your student's math skills?
Then take a look at Numeracy Ninjas!
http://www.numeracyninjas.org/
shared_text:
Numeracy Ninjas ‚Äì A completely free KS3 numeracy intervention
Numeracy Ninjas is a free Key Stage 3 numeracy intervention designed to fill gaps in students‚Äô basic mental calculation strategies and also to empower them with the numeracy skills and fluency required to fully access GCSE Maths concepts when they move to Key Stage 4 study.

Numeracy Ninjas ‚Äì A completely free KS3 numeracy intervention

post_text: Last Friday, St. Helens Elementary celebrated their Students of the Month with a Principal's Luncheon! Give a hand to these wonderful Superstars!
shared_text:
St. Helens Elementary School
February 28 at 10:44 PM ¬∑

There's a lot to celebrate for Friday's Feature.

Today was the Principal's Luncheon for our Students of the Month. We had the best conversations and a little fun with some crowns.

Mrs. Schiller's class made oobleck. Superstars weren't too sure what to think about it, but it was lots of fun!

Don't forget that Monday is Read Across America. It is a celebration of Dr. Seuss. Don't forget to come to school dressed as your favorite Dr. Seuss character!

post_text:
Mainstage Theatre's Winter community show, Too Much Light Makes the Baby Go Blind: 45 plays in 90 minutes, will open Friday, February 28 and continue February 29th, March 6 and 7 at 7:30 p.m. and March 7th at 2 p.m. Audience members choose the order of the plays, all done in a 90 minute time frame. When 90 minutes is up, the show is over! Rated PG-13 for mild language and mature content. All tickets are $5 and are available online at https://danabrownmainstage.ludus.com/index.php, at the RAL ASB Office, or at the door.

All of these events are at the Dana Brown Mainstage Theatre at R.A. Long H.S. 2903 Nichols Blvd. Longview. For more information, visit Mainstage Theatre's Facebook page or email Susan Donahue at sdonahue@longview.k12.wa.us
text:
Mainstage Theatre's Winter community show, Too Much Light Makes the Baby Go Blind: 45 plays in 90 minutes, will open Friday, February 28 and continue February 29th, March 6 and 7 at 7:30 p.m. and March 7th at 2 p.m. Audience members choose the order of the plays, all done in a 90 minute time frame. When 90 minutes is up, the show is over! Rated PG-13 for mild language and mature content. All tickets are $5 and are available online at https://danabrownmainstage.ludus.com/index.php, at the RAL ASB Office, or at the door.

All of these events are at the Dana Brown Mainstage Theatre at R.A. Long H.S. 2903 Nichols Blvd. Longview. For more information, visit Mainstage Theatre's Facebook page or email Susan Donahue at sdonahue@longview.k12.wa.us

Mint Valley Elementary School added 45 new photos to the album: Mr. Johnsen's Squid Project ‚Äî at Mint Valley Elementary School.
February ¬∑

Mr. Johnsen's class is studying the life cycle of squid, and today the got to observe the exterior of some small squid in the classroom. Tomorrow is their big day though. They get to study and record their observations of the interior of the squid. What a great experience for our your scientists.

In case you missed it, A group from Vancouver Public Schools and the Washington State School of Medicine visited the R.A. Long High School high-tech STEM lab to experience the Anatomage table. The anatomage table allows for three dimensional viewing and dissection of human and animal bodies in high definition.

Take a look at our demonstration of the cardiovascular system through the Anatomage table in this video!
text:
In case you missed it, A group from Vancouver Public Schools and the Washington State School of Medicine visited the R.A. Long High School high-tech STEM lab to experience the Anatomage table. The anatomage table allows for three dimensional viewing and dissection of human and animal bodies in high definition.

Take a look at our demonstration of the cardiovascular system through the Anatomage table in this video!

post_text: A group from Vancouver Public Schools and the Washington State School of Medicine visited the R.A. Long High School high-tech STEM lab to experience the Anatomage table. The anatomage table allows for three dimensional viewing and dissection of human and animal bodies in high definition. The table was recently updated to also show the heart beat pulsing and blood flow through veins to help students learn human body systems. The high-tech STEM lab is part of the district‚Äôs CTE/Vocational program to prepare students to work ready, college ready or military ready after graduation.

This means voters don‚Äôt have to provide a stamp or go to a ballot box to vote. Instead, they can simply fill out the ballot, put into the provided postage paid envelope and drop into the mail.

A special election is coming up soon. So don't forget to vote!

post_text:
This message was sent to the parents and families of Mark Morris students today (February 3, 2020):

Dear Mark Morris Parents and Families,

An unexpected heating system problem occurred at Mark Morris today. The heating issue is in the process of being fixed right now. To fix the problem the heat to the building has temporarily been shut off. Classes will continue as planned for today. Mark Morris administrators will be monitoring classroom temperatures to make sure students and staff members remain comfortable.

Given the heating issue, the Mark Morris girls varsity basketball game, scheduled for tonight at 7pm at Mark Morris, has been moved to Lower Columbia College at 7pm. The Monarch girls JV basketball game, scheduled for today, will be rescheduled. All other after school activities scheduled for today are cancelled. Information about any additional scheduling changes will be sent to parents via Skyward email and posted to the district web site and Facebook page. We appreciate your patience as we get the problem fixed.

Please call the office if you have questions at 360-575-7663.
text:
This message was sent to the parents and families of Mark Morris students today (February 3, 2020):

Dear Mark Morris Parents and Families,

An unexpected heating system problem occurred at Mark Morris today. The heating issue is in the process of being fixed right now. To fix the problem the heat to the building has temporarily been shut off. Classes will continue as planned for today. Mark Morris administrators will be monitoring classroom temperatures to make sure students and staff members remain comfortable.

Given the heating issue, the Mark Morris girls varsity basketball game, scheduled for tonight at 7pm at Mark Morris, has been moved to Lower Columbia College at 7pm. The Monarch girls JV basketball game, scheduled for today, will be rescheduled. All other after school activities scheduled for today are cancelled. Information about any additional scheduling changes will be sent to parents via Skyward email and posted to the district web site and Facebook page. We appreciate your patience as we get the problem fixed.

Please call the office if you have questions at 360-575-7663.

Congratulations to our Mustangs of the Week for 1/21-1/24. These kids need to get major congratulations for showing us all how to have a great week during a short school week. Five more of our teachers are now Nationally Board Certified! These five fantastic teachers include: Ronda Butterfield from Robert Gray Elementary, Nicole Campbell from Cascade Middle School, Paul Field from R.A. Long High School, Jenessa Norvaisis from CVG Elementary, and Joel Thomas from St. Helens Elementary. The school board will be recognizing them on February 10.

To read more about our Nationally Board Certified teachers, visit our website: https://longviewschools.com/2020/01/17/five-teachers-earn-national-board-certification/

ESD 112 wrote an article on the school districts that have a levy, replacement levy, and/or bond on the Feb. 11th special election ballot.

As for our district, we will have an educational programs replacement levy on the ballot for Feb. 11th. So don't forget to get out there and vote!
shared_text:
ESD112.ORG
17 districts in ESD 112 region seeking voter-approved school funding in Feb. special election

ESD 112
January 17 at 6:39 PM ¬∑

In the Feb. 11 special election, 17 out of 30 school districts in the ESD 112 region will have a levy, replacement levy, and/or bond on the ballot. Visit our website to learn about school funding and these important measures, and make sure you're registered to vote before the election!
.
.
.

post_text: School related tax rates have dropped dramatically since 2013. Homeowners are paying a much lower tax rate to support schools than they have in years. The current educational levy expires in 2020 and there's a measure on the February ballot to replace it. Please vote by February 11.

post_text:
Zoom on over to R. A. Long Science Olympiad's 7th annual Elementary Science Olympiad Day Camp Friday January 24th, or Friday March 13th!

This event is for any elementary student who would like to explore the electrifying world of science! They will be divided into teams of 3-6 to work on many fantastic projects from rockets, to dino digging, to cracking codes, and much more! (under close supervision of course)

If you would like to know more about this wonderful event, contact Mrs. Burleson or Mrs. Gonzalez at:
hburleson@longview.k12.wa.us
ggonzalez@longview.k12.wa.us

This winter break Mark Morris High School will be having a "Christmas Catch Up" for students that are struggling to pass their courses.

This event is for any student that is failing a course. It will be January 2nd-3rd from 9am-12pm in the Mark Morris Cafeteria, Library and LGIC. Please don't miss out on this fantastic opportunity this winter season!

Food and transportation will be provided to students that attend the event. There is no need to sign up.

For more information please contact Mark Morris High School.

post_text:
Students at R.A. Long took the MS Word 2019 Exam! So far 12 of them have passed and earned their MS certifications, which is state and nationally recognized as an important credential in various industries. Each certificate also equals as dual college credits at LCC.

The students in the photo are the fantastic individuals who passed this exam and earn their certificates! They are; Jetzibe Rocha-Andrade, Cardin Chung (Word & PowerPoint), Kevin Martinez, Aiden Wade, Silas Burchim, and Conner Person, Gavin Gorman (not pictured). Congratulations!
text:

Mr. Huff and Mrs. McDonald's classes were awarded root beer floats for collecting the most box for K-2 and 3-5. Every penny we get in box tops goes right back into the school through the PTO. Thanks again to all who sent in box tops as to support our school. We look forward to the box tops competition which will happen again in the spring. Congratulations Mr. Huff and Mrs. McDonald's classes. Thank you so much to our wonderful PTO for supporting these contest for our kiddos, and for doing so much for our school everyday.

November 22, 2019 at 1:14 PM ¬∑ Longview, WA ¬∑

Bingo Night started with an idea from leadership students. Our students are amazing future leaders who want to make a difference in their school community. I could not be more proud of how much the leadership students stepped up yesterday. We now can pay it forward and give the proceeds from our Food Drive to our own Family Community Resource Center which serves not only students in our building but students community wide. Thank you to all the staff, parents, and businesses who made Monticello Bingo Night possible.

post_text: Mt. Solo's Pink Out raised $484.01 for The Lower Columbia Regional Cancer Center this year! Congratulations Skyhawks!
shared_text:
Mt. Solo Middle School
November 25, 2019 at 6:25 PM ¬∑

Our 4th Annual Pink Out raised $484.01 and it was donated today to The Lower Columbia Regional Cancer Center. One fund raising event was face painting, these students pictured were some of the painters! We hope that we raised cancer awareness and that the patients and their families will be comforted this holiday season! #longviewwamtsoloskyhawks

post_text:
Columbia Valley Gardens Elementary is continuing their Sock & Glove Drive to support the Project Homeless Connect (PHC) service fair on January 23rd. Help someone stay warm this winter! Please bring donations to CVG or Lower Columbia CAP.

This collections will continue until November 27th.

For more information, please contact Lower Columbia CAP at ginan@lowercolumbiacap.org

post_text:
Don't miss out on the 7th annual Madrigal Dinner!
Featuring a four course meal by a professional chef and performances by both R.A. Long and Mark Morris Choirs, come be transported into a medieval world full of song, food, and joyous holiday cheer. Start your holiday season off right and support the Mark Morris and RA Long Choir Programs!

Friday, December 6, at 7:30 PM (RAL Night)
Saturday, December 7, at 7:30 PM (Mark Morris Night)

Tickets are $30 and can be purchased online and in person at either Mark Morris or RA Long ASB offices.

Online Tickets can be purchased by going to: https://wa-longview.intouchreceipting.com

Create a new account, click to shop items at all schools, High schools, RA Long, Madrigal

post_text:
This year, Discovery High School created their first Student Leadership team! Their Student Leaders have organized two successful, school-wide events! Last week, they had two Cispus Learning Center Challenge Course directors lead them through a two hour training. Below are photos from that training.

We are proud of our Student Leaders and hope they continue to use their leadership skills in every aspect of their lives.

post_text: Mint Valley Elementary celebrates their Mustangs of the Week!
shared_text:
Mint Valley Elementary School
November 19, 2019 at 8:16 PM ¬∑

Mustangs of the Week

Congratulations to the Mustangs of the Week for 11/12-11/15. As the holidays draw closer our students each have different reactions to the distractions that come along with this time of year. When we honor our Mustangs, whether for the week or the month, we celebrate all of the fantastic things that they were caught doing. We have amazing students here at Mint Valley, and we couldn't be more proud of our students. Here's to all of them giving us their best.
